title: War in Sudan: Death strikes at every corner  in devastated Khartoum
summary: 'In Sudan, a total war' (1/8). Since April 15, 2023, the conflict between General al-Burhan's forces and General Hemedti's militias may have claimed the lives of over 150,000 civilians. Le Monde reports from the army-controlled areas of Sudan in the first part of a series on a country where the hopes of the 2019 revolution have been shattered by war, now fueling the world's worst humanitarian crisis.

title: What happens to Donald Trump's legal cases now?
summary: Seriously implicated in four separate criminal cases, Trump will now likely be able to avoid the trials that would have awaited him if he had lost the election.

title: Israeli minister reports some progress toward cease-fire but Hezbollah unaware
summary: Israeli Foreign Minister Gideon Saar said any agreement would have to include enforcement mechanisms to prevent Hezbollah from reconstituting its military infrastructure near the border.

title: New Haiti PM sworn in, promises to 'restore security'
summary: The Caribbean nation has long struggled with political instability, poverty, natural disasters and gang violence. But conditions sharply worsened at the end of February when armed groups launched coordinated attacks in the capital Port-au-Prince, saying they wanted to overthrow then-prime minister Ariel Henry.

title: US presidential election: Between cynicism and bitterness, late night shows take note of Trump's victory
summary: These American TV institutions, which mix humor and politics, have traditionally been critical of the president-elect.

title: 'Sexual violence can be explained not only by a lack of education, but also by a lack of interest and activism by men'
summary: Men's growing awareness of sexual violence against women owes a great deal to feminist raising awareness work, which is not given the recognition it deserves, writes researcher Florian Vörös.

title: COP29: 'Environmental and human rights issues are inextricably linked'
summary: With the 29th Climate Change Conference beginning in Baku on November 11, a collective of academics and artists calls on the international community – and France in particular – to take a stand against the Azerbaijani government and oligarchs, in an op-ed piece for 'Le Monde.'

title: US military strikes Iranian-backed militia targets in Syria
summary: Since the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas in Israel, and Israel's large-scale response in Gaza, Iran-backed fighters who are loosely allied with Hamas have carried out drone and rocket attacks on bases housing US troops in Iraq and Syria.

title: COP29: Nations approve new standards on carbon markets
summary: Nearly 200 nations agreed on a number of crucial ground rules for a credible, UN-backed international carbon market, enabling countries to trade high-quality carbon credits to help meet climate targets.

title: Spirit Airlines says flight to Haiti's capital hit by gunfire
summary: Flight 951 from Fort Lauderdale, Florida to Port-au-Prince was diverted and landed safely in neighboring Dominican Republic, Spirit said in a statement. The Haitian capital is largely controlled by powerful, well-armed gangs.

title: Trump demands Senate bypass votes to confirm appointees
summary: Under the US Constitution, the Senate must vote to approve nominations made by the president for senior executive positions, such as cabinet posts and judicial appointments. A constitutional clause, however, allows for presidents to bypass a Senate vote if the chamber is in an extended recess.

title: 2024 will be hottest year on record and exceed 1.5°C warming for first time
summary: In its provisional report on the state of the climate in 2024, published on Monday, November 11, the World Meteorological Organization said global average temperatures will be 1.54°C warmer than the preindustrial era. It issued 'a Red Alert at the sheer pace of climate change in a single generation.'

title: Italian judges deal new blow to Albania migrant scheme
summary: The ruling challenges Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni's plan to process migrants outside the EU, highlighting conflicts between Italian and European immigration laws.

title: Agricultural problems persist in Europe as farmers plan protests
summary: Like in France, farmers' organizations in Belgium and Poland are denouncing the free trade agreement negotiated between the European Union and the MERCOSUR countries. Action is being planned.

title: Lessons from the first Jewish immigrants to Palestine
summary: The leaders of the first wave of Jewish immigration to Palestine at the end of the 19th century were already in no doubt about the inevitability of conflict with the land's Arab population.

title: COP29: 'Supporting the fight against climate change in the global South is not one of the North's priorities'
summary: Romain Weikmans, an international relations professor, explains the obstacles to financial transfers between global North and South countries to fund the green transition, a core issue of the Baku climate conference.

title: Pope's planned visit to Corsica sparks tension
summary: Francis is expected on the French island around December 14-15. However, he has declined an invitation to Paris to attend the reopening of Notre-Dame a week before, which has irritated the French presidency.

title: Trump says former ICE director Tom Homan will be appointed 'border czar'
summary: Tom Homan, the former acting director of US Immigration and Customs Enforcement under Donald Trump's first presidency, will be tasked with overseeing the mass deportations that were a core campaign promise.

title: COP29 opens in a more perilous context than ever for the climate
summary: Donald Trump's election comes as geopolitical tensions run high and the US faces a sluggish economy. The challenge at this year's COP will be to reach an agreement on financing to keep climate negotiations on track.

title: Judge to rule on throwing out Trump hush money conviction
summary: Due to be sentenced on November 26, the Republican President-elect may receive a reprieve if Judge Juan Merchan decides to dismiss the case following the Supreme Court's recent ruling on presidential immunity.

title: At the Musée d'Art Moderne in Paris, an exhibition struggling to take off
summary: Profuse but incomplete, 'The Atomic Age: Artists Put to the Test of History,' focuses on artists' views of the nuclear threat, yet struggles to find coherence.

title: Trump names former Rep. Lee Zeldin to lead EPA, adviser Stephen Miller to be deputy chief of policy
summary: New York Republican chair Ed Cox said Zeldin's surprise appointment was 'a testament to President Trump’s commitment to revitalizing the original mission of the EPA – an agency created ... under President Richard Nixon to protect our nation’s environment.'

title: In Laos, in the capital of the Golden Triangle, drops of legality in an ocean of crime
summary: The worst stories are circulating about this new city along the Mekong River, granted in 2007 for 99 years to a Chinese gambling magnate by the name of Zhao Wei.

title: 'In the US as in France, immigration has become a powerful vehicle for expressing social malaise and challenging elites'
summary: In both France and the United States, there are numerous examples of a disconnect between proposed policies and the realities of migration, observes Le Monde's Philippe Bernard in his column.

title: COP29 spends its first day in the shadow of Donald Trump
summary: After opening in Azerbaijan on Monday, COP29 has until November 22 to reach an agreement on funding the 'green' transition of developing countries. This effort is under strain due to Donald Trump's return to the US presidency in 2025. Trump has called global warming a 'hoax,' while the World Meteorological Organization warns that the year 2024 will mark the first temperature increase over 1.5°C.

title: In Sweden, the prime minister's wife's clerical dress causes controversy
summary: Ulf Kristersson's wife, Birgitta Ed, was ordained a priest in January 2023. Since then, she's worn her clerical collar consistently, sparking heated debate in Sweden.

title: Trump's first appointments reflect focus on immigration
summary: Without waiting for his inauguration on January 20, 2025, the president-elect has unveiled the names of the loyalists who will make up his future administration. He wants the Senate to waive the confirmation procedure for these choices.

title: Possible visit of Bezalel Smotrich to Paris causes controversy
summary: Israel's openly supremacist finance minister is expected in Paris on Wednesday for a gala evening organized by the organization Israel is Forever.

title: Le Monde and several French newspapers sue X over 'neighboring rights' payments
summary: Several news organizations accused the social media platform formerly known as Twitter of running their content without payment.

title: Bayssour, the Druze village in solidarity with displaced Shiites in southern Lebanon
summary: A stronghold of resistance to the Israeli invasion of 1982, the town in the Chouf region has opened its doors wide to the inhabitants of the border region, under bombardment by Israel.

title: Can a political earthquake like Donald Trump's election happen in France?
summary: As in the United States, polarization is at work in France, fueled by feelings of relegation among the working class and of downgrading among the middle class, Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz writes.

title: 'The fate of Tesla hangs on Elon Musk's relationship with the Trump administration'
summary: The Tesla boss wants to become the champion of autonomous driving but the sector is tightly controlled in the United States. The billionaire, expected to be the new head of administrative efficiency under Trump, intends to loosen the regulatory straitjacket.

title: Arab and Muslim countries raise their voices against Israel
summary: As Saudi Arabia and Iran continue their rapprochement, the Gulf States have called for a ceasefire in Gaza and Lebanon.

title: In Arizona, Democrat Gallego wins over Trump loyalist to become state's first Latino US senator
summary: Nearly a week after the presidential election, Ruben Gallego was declared the winner of the Arizona Senate race pitting him against former TV presenter Kari Lake.

title: Watch: Scale of Gaza's destruction before and after Israeli bombardments
summary: Footage filmed in the Gaza Strip before and after October 7 shows the extent of destruction in the Palestinian enclave. At least 58.7% of the territory's buildings have been damaged or destroyed, according to the lowest estimates.

title: COP29: UK's Starmer pledges 81% emissions cut by 2035
summary: Prime Minister Keir Starmer unveiled the new target as he attended the beginning of the COP29 climate conference in Baku, Azerbaijan, where he is one of the only G20 leaders to show up.

title: Archbishop of Canterbury Justin Welby resigns over abuse scandal
summary: Justin Welby, the leader of the Anglican church, announced the move after a report revealed that the Church of England had, since 2013, covered up decades of abuse by John Smyth, a lawyer who organized evangelical summer camps.

title: Drinking water in France threatened with non-compliance due to 'forever chemical'
summary: The country's water resources are massively contaminated by a molecule produced by the degradation of flufenacet, a pesticide that was recently classified as an endocrine disruptor. Associations have called for an urgent ban of the product.

title: War in Sudan: The ordeal of those besieged on Tuti Island
summary: 'In Sudan, a total war' (2/8). Tuti Island was a garden island in the heart of Khartoum until the civil war broke out in April 2023. Connected to the capital by a bridge over the Nile, this once-popular spot for family outings has become a hellish place.

title: Geologist Raymonde Bonnefille: 'The discovery of Lucy was a collective effort'
summary: The pollen specialist was part of the expedition that unearthed the Australopithecus afarensis in northeastern Ethiopia in 1974. In an interview with Le Monde, she looks back at the circumstances surrounding the major discovery.

title: Trump's sentencing decision in hush money case delayed until November 19
summary: A judge on Tuesday put off a key ruling in the president-elect's criminal case as his lawyers argued for dismissing it so he can run the country.

title: French MPs reject massively amended 2025 budget
summary: The Assemblée Nationale rejected an opposition-amended budget filled with new taxes, pushing Prime Minister Michel Barnier's government to submit a revised bill to the Sénat for further compromise.

title: What science really says on the link between organic food and health
summary: Multiple studies show the benefits of organic food, including lower risks of some cancers, obesity and congenital malformations, even if the number of studies remains too small to establish an unquestionable causal link.

title: Strike calls surge across French transport sector
summary: Air transport unions have called for strikes on Thursday, November 14, to protest the increase in airline ticket taxes, while rail unions are planning an indefinite strike starting December 11 to oppose the dismantling of one of their subsidiaries.

title: US says Israel not found in violation of law on Gaza aid
summary: The finding comes despite Israel not meeting several requirements outlined in a letter from the US last month, which expressed concern over Gaza's humanitarian crisis, including the need to allow at least 350 trucks per day into the region.

title: Trump names Waltz as national security ambassador; Huckabee as ambassador to Israel
summary: Donald Trump confirmed former Green Beret and China hawk Mike Waltz as his pick for national security advisor and nominated former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee as ambassador to Israel.

title: In France, concern grows over redundancy plans
summary: Layoffs are rising across sectors including automotive, retail and chemicals. Politicians and trade unions are discussing how to stem further job losses.

title: Lebanon: at least 33 dead after Israeli strikes across the country
summary: The attacks targeted not only known Hezbollah strongholds such as the southern suburbs of Beirut, but also areas where the Iran-backed group has not traditionally had a presence.

title: Pentagon leaker Jack Teixeira sentenced to 15 years in prison
summary: The leak exposed to the world unvarnished secret assessments of Russia's war in Ukraine, including information about troop movements in Ukraine, and the provision of supplies and equipment to Ukrainian troops.

title: German employees are Europe's sick leave champions
summary: Economists view this as a significant impediment to growth recovery, with several analysts suggesting that the economic losses stemming from these absences could amount to the crucial half percentage point of GDP needed to lift the country out of recession.

title: UN condemns 'acts reminiscent of the gravest international crimes' in Gaza, as Washington clears Israel on aid compliance
summary: The UN statement coincides with Hamas's accusation on Tuesday that the United States is complicit in what it termed a "genocidal war" in Gaza.

title: British writer Samantha Harvey wins Booker Prize for fiction
summary: Harvey was awarded the 50,000-pound ($64,000) prize for "Orbital," a book she has called a "space pastoral."
